content:
Editor in chief

Arlington resident Josh Riney holds his hand to his heart while watching the Arlington Fourth of July Parade on July  outside of College Park Center PERIOD Riney is a  UTA alumnus PERIOD

Arlington resident Kent Miller said he has attended the Arlington Fourth of July parade as long as he can remember PERIOD

During his childhood Miller would ride his bicycle in the parade as a member of the Boy Scouts of America PERIOD  As a father now he walks the parade while his son rides with the Boy Scouts PERIOD

We just come out here and be patriotic and support our local community and celebrate the nation he said PERIOD

UTA ambassadors alumni PresidentVistasp Karbhari and his wife Lisa Karbhari ride parade floats and wave to the cheering crowd in the Arlington Fourth of July Parade on July  PERIOD

Miller said he changes his Fourth of July ensemble every year PERIOD This year he sported a floppy Uncle Sam hat red and blue shorts with stars and a starshaped balloon tied to his lawn chair PERIOD

Miller was one of many dressed in celebration at the Thursday parade in downtown Arlington PERIOD

People clad in red white and blue and stars and stripes filled the streets surrounding the UTA campus while drums sirens cheers and laughter echoed off buildings PERIOD

Claudia Perkins Arlington Fourth of July parade association board member said Arlingtons parade is the largest one in Texas with up to  to  attendees PERIOD

Professional cosplayer Chelle Jacobs said it was her second time participating in the Arlington parade as part of her cosplay group PERIOD

Professional cosplayer Chelle Jacobs said this is her second time attending the Arlington parade PERIOD Her cosplay group will ride in the parade dressed as The Pirates of the Caribbean PERIOD pic.twitter.comchnfZgCS7R

Everything is so big and fun Jacobs said PERIOD Its a celebration. its a popular event because everyone in the city is welcoming visitors she said and Arlington is conveniently located where anyone in the Metroplex can attend PERIOD

Allen resident Ola Ojo cheers on parade participants during the Arlington Fourth of July Parade on July  at South West Street PERIOD Ojo came with her Arlingtonbased church PERIOD

Elvis Presley imitator Brian Schober said he has attended the parade for the last seven years because of its size PERIOD

People need the joy of seeing a grown man dressed as Elvis riding a little bike Schober said PERIOD

Dressed in a black wig sparkly sunglasses and a red white and gold pantsuit Schober rode his motorcycle up and down the streets performing tricks PERIOD

Electrical engineering sophomore Kolin Kilpatrick said this was his first time attending the Arlington parade PERIOD

Its a lot of people and its actually a lot of really cool floats he said PERIOD A lot of them are from people instead of you know when businesses come together and just kind of shamelessly advertise PERIOD So yeah I think its pretty neat. the Arlington Fourth of July Parade made its way around College Park Center and downtown Arlington on July  PERIOD The parade was filled with high school marching bands local organizations with floats UTA students and Arlington city officials PERIOD

The event was started in  and has grown from a small collection of children on bicycles into the large event it is now PERIOD





































CecilLenzen

featureseditor.shorthornuta.edu

Editor in chief
